How to Install free42-nologo on debian

  • Home
  • debian
  • free42-nologo

Today in this tutorial, I’ll show you how you can install free42-nologo on debian with and without using the command line.

Introduction

Installing free42-nologo on debian is very easy. And with the help of this tutorial, you will be able to easily install, update and uninstall free42-nologo in just a few steps.

In this tutorial I’ll show you four methods to install free42-nologo, the methods are using apt, apt-get, aptitude, and synaptic. All these methods require you to have an active and stable internet connection and sudo permission.

Install free42-nologo Using apt

To install free42-nologo in debian using apt, you will need to run the apt update command first to get the updated list of packages from the repositories.

Copy the command given below and paste it in the command line, then press enter. If you are using the sudo command for the first time then you might also need to enter your root password.

sudo apt update

After you have updated the package list using apt, you can now install free42-nologo using the apt install command. To do that use the command given below.

sudo apt -y install free42-nologo

The installation of free42-nologo might take a little bit of time depending upon your internet connection and machine configuration.

Install free42-nologo Using apt-get

To install free42-nologo using apt-get in debian, you will need to first update the package list using the apt-get update command. Copy, paste, and enter the command given below in the command line.

sudo apt-get update

After updating the package lists, use the apt-get install command given below to install free42-nologo.

sudo apt-get -y install free42-nologo

Install free42-nologo Using Synaptic

To install free42-nologo using Synaptic you will need to first install Synaptic, you can do that by following the instructions from here. After installing synaptic follow the steps below to install free42-nologo on your debian using Synaptic.

You can open synaptic by clicking on the menu icon then searching for synaptic or you can open the command line and enter the command given below –

sudo synaptic

After synaptic opens, click on the search icon and search for free42-nologo. This will display the free42-nologo package in the package window, now to install free42-nologo, click on the checkbox that is on the left side.

Then click on Mark for Installation, this will select the free42-nologo package for installation, now to install it click on the Apply button, you will get a summary window where click on the apply button again to start the download of free42-nologo.

If the download and installation are successful then the checkmark option will turn green.

Install free42-nologo Using aptitude

To install free42-nologo on debian using aptitude, you will need to first install Aptitude in your debian. To install Aptitude follow the instructions here. Once you have aptitude installed proceed to the installation of free42-nologo.

Now you will need to first update your package lists from the repositories, use the apt update command for that, after that update the package list of aptitude using the aptitude update command.

sudo apt update sudo aptitude update

After updating the package list of aptitude, install free42-nologo using the command aptitude install free42-nologo.

sudo aptitude -y install free42-nologo

How to Upgrade free42-nologo on debian

If you want to upgrade the free42-nologo package on your debian to its latest version then here’s how you can do that using apt, apt-get, aptitude, and synaptic.

Upgrade free42-nologo using Apt & Apt-get

To upgrade free42-nologo to its latest version using apt or apt-get, you will need to open the terminal then run the sudo apt update command to update the package list, after that copy and paste the commands given below to upgrade free42-nologo.

sudo apt install --only-upgrade free42-nologo sudo apt-get install --only-upgrade free42-nologo

Upgrade free42-nologo using Aptitude

To upgrade free42-nologo using aptitude you will need to again run the update command to update the package list, use command sudo aptitude update to do that. After that run the command given below to upgrade free42-nologo.

sudo aptitude -y full-upgrade free42-nologo

Upgrade free42-nologo using Synaptic

To upgrade free42-nologo using synaptic open synaptic using the command sudo synaptic or by going to the menu and searching for synaptic.

In synaptic click on the reload button, this will look for updates. After that you will need to search for free42-nologo, now right-click free42-nologo, and click on the mark for upgrade option.

Now to upgrade free42-nologo just click on the apply button, then click on the apply button again in the summary screen.

How To Uninstall free42-nologo on debian

If you want to remove and uninstall free42-nologo from your debian then here’s how you can do that. To remove just free42-nologo, you can use the command that is given below, copy the command, paste it in the command line then press enter.

sudo apt remove free42-nologo

Remove related packages, dependencies & configuration files of free42-nologo

To remove all the related packages, dependencies and configuration files of free42-nologo you can use the command given below.

sudo apt -y purge free42-nologo

Remove free42-nologo using Synaptic Package Manager

You can also uninstall free42-nologo using the synaptic package manager, first open synaptic using the command sudo synaptic or search and open it directly.

After that in synaptic search for free42-nologo, right-click the free42-nologo package and click on the Mark for Complete Removal option. Now to uninstall free42-nologo click on the apply button then in summary click on apply again.

Conclusion

That is how you can install free42-nologo on debian using the command line or using the synaptic package manager. I also showed you how you can uninstall and upgrade free42-nologo using the command line or using the synaptic package manager.

If you need any help regarding the installation of free42-nologo then send me a mail at netmikoblog@gmail.com, thank you.
